beginner.title: Hello World
beginner.content: Welcome to Python! The print function is used to output text to the console. In Python, strings (text) must be enclosed in single (') or double (") quotes.
hints: Make sure your text is inside quotes.

beginner.title: Variables
beginner.content: Variables are containers for storing data values. Python has no command for declaring a variable. A variable is created the moment you first assign a value to it.

beginner.title: Data Types
beginner.content: Python has built-in data types like integers, floats, strings, and booleans. You can check the type of a variable using the type() function.
beginner.example:
x = 5
y = 3.14
z = 'Hello'
print(type(x))
print(type(y))
print(type(z))

beginner.title: If...Else
beginner.content: Python supports logical conditions from mathematics. These can be used in 'if' statements.
beginner.example:
a = 33
b = 200
if b > a:
  print('b is greater than a')
hints: Use ':' at the end of the if statement.

beginner.title: While Loops
beginner.content: With the while loop we can execute a set of statements as long as a condition is true.
hints: Don't forget to increment the counter, or the loop will run forever!

intermediate.title: Lists
intermediate.content: Lists are used to store multiple items in a single variable. Lists are ordered, changeable, and allow duplicate values.

intermediate.title: Dictionaries
intermediate.content: Dictionaries are used to store data values in key:value pairs. A dictionary is a collection which is ordered, changeable and does not allow duplicates.

intermediate.title: Functions
intermediate.content: A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called. You can pass data, known as parameters, into a function.

advanced.title: List Comprehensions
advanced.content: List comprehension offers a shorter syntax when you want to create a new list based on the values of an existing list.
advanced.example:
fruits = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry', 'kiwi', 'mango']
newlist = [x for x in fruits if 'a' in x]
print(newlist)
hints: Syntax: [expression for item in iterable if condition]

advanced.title: Lambda Functions
advanced.content: A lambda function is a small anonymous function. A lambda function can take any number of arguments, but can only have one expression.

advanced.title: Classes and Objects
advanced.content: Python is an object oriented programming language. Almost everything in Python is an object, with its properties and methods.

data_science.title: NumPy Basics
data_science.content: NumPy is the fundamental package for scientific computing in Python. It provides support for arrays, matrices, and high-level mathematical functions.
data_science.example:
import numpy as np
arr = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
print(arr)
print(arr.mean())

data_science.title: Pandas DataFrames
data_science.content: Pandas is a fast, powerful, flexible and easy to use open source data analysis and manipulation tool.
data_science.example:
import pandas as pd
data = {'Name': ['Tom', 'Jerry'], 'Age': [20, 21]}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
print(df)
hints: DataFrame is the main data structure.

data_science.title: Matplotlib Visualization
data_science.content: Matplotlib is a comprehensive library for creating static, animated, and interactive visualizations in Python.
data_science.example:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y = np.sin(x)
print('Plotting sin(x)... (Visualization not supported in text output)')

machine_learning.title: Linear Regression
machine_learning.content: Linear Regression is a basic predictive analytics technique. It attempts to model the relationship between two variables by fitting a linear equation.
machine_learning.example:
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
import numpy as np
X = np.array([[1], [2], [3], [4]])
y = np.array([2, 4, 6, 8])
model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X, y)
print(model.predict([[5]]))

machine_learning.title: Model Evaluation
machine_learning.content: Evaluating your model is crucial. Common metrics include Mean Squared Error (MSE) for regression and Accuracy for classification.
machine_learning.example:
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error
y_true = [3, -0.5, 2, 7]
y_pred = [2.5, 0.0, 2, 8]
print(mean_squared_error(y_true, y_pred))

nlp.title: Tokenization with spaCy
nlp.content: Tokenization is the task of chopping it up into pieces, called tokens, perhaps at the same time throwing away certain characters, such as punctuation.
nlp.example:
import spacy
# Note: Requires 'en_core_web_sm' model installed
# nlp = spacy.load('en_core_web_sm')
print('spaCy installed. Load model to tokenize.')

nlp.title: Transformers
nlp.content: Transformers are the state-of-the-art architecture for NLP. The 'transformers' library by Hugging Face provides easy access to these models.
nlp.example:
from transformers import pipeline
print('Transformers library imported successfully.')
hints: Models can be large to download.

advanced_ai.title: RAG Systems
advanced_ai.content: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) combines an information retrieval component with a text generator model.
advanced_ai.example: print('RAG involves retrieving documents and passing them to an LLM.')

advanced_ai.title: Knowledge Graphs
advanced_ai.content: A Knowledge Graph represents a network of real-world entities—i.e. objects, events, situations, or concepts—and illustrates the relationship between them.
advanced_ai.example:
import networkx as nx
G = nx.Graph()
G.add_edge('Paris', 'France')
print(G.edges())

deployment.title: FastAPI
deployment.content: FastAPI is a modern, fast (high-performance), web framework for building APIs with Python 3.7+ based on standard Python type hints.
deployment.example:
from fastapi import FastAPI
app = FastAPI()
print('FastAPI app created.')
